item.title: Matt Hancock quits as health secretary after breaking social distance guidance
item.description: His successor Sajid Javid says he is "honoured" to take on the role at a critical time in the pandemic.

item.title: Sajid Javid: Who is the new health secretary?
item.description: The second-generation immigrant son of a bus driver previously served Boris Johnson as chancellor.

item.title: Florida building collapse: Fifth body found in survivor hunt
item.description: It comes after a 2018 report highlighting a "major error" in the building's design was made public.

item.title: Milton Keynes: Police find seriously injured child and dead man
item.description: The shooting incident in Milton Keynes has prompted a mandatory referral to the policing watchdog.

item.title: Covid: NSW sees 30 new Covid cases as Sydney locks down
item.description: New South Wales reports 30 new cases on the second day of Greater Sydney's two-week lockdown.

item.title: Covid-19: Crowds flee Dhaka ahead of strict Bangladesh lockdown
item.description: Cases of Covid-19 in Bangladesh have surged since May, largely because of the Delta variant.

item.title: Wales out of Euro 2020 after 4-0 thrashing
item.description: Wales are knocked out of Euro 2020 in the second round by Denmark, whose inspiring journey at the tournament continues to the quarter-finals.

item.title: Hot air balloon crash kills four in Albuquerque, New Mexico
item.description: The balloon is reported to have hit a power line, before the basket detached and fell to the ground.

item.title: Colombia offers reward after presidential helicopter shooting
item.description: President IvÃ¡n Duque's helicopter was shot at as he flew near the Venezuelan border on Friday.

item.title: LAX: Man jumps from plane after trying to access cockpit
item.description: The man, who fled via the emergency slide, was detained on the taxiway at Los Angeles Airport.

item.title: Germany knife attack: Three killed were all women
item.description: The suspect has been charged with three counts of murder and five counts of grievous bodily harm.

item.title: Italy 2-1 Austria (aet): Azzurri survive scare to reach Euro 2020 quarter-finals
item.description: Italy require extra time to see off battling Austria at Wembley and set up a Euro 2020 quarter-final against Belgium or Portugal.

item.title: The Papers: 'Matt finished' as 'humiliated' Hancock quits
item.description: The former health secretary's departure after kissing senior aide dominates Sunday's papers.

item.title: China's changes through one man's lens
item.description: Yan Zhigang has spent four decades photographing the streets, and the people, of China.

item.title: The LGBT people forced 'back in the closet' when they enter residential care
item.description: Rita spent her final years in sheltered accommodation where she felt forced to keep her sexuality secret.

item.title: Henry VIII: Uncovering the Mary Rose's ethnically diverse crew
item.description: Archaeologists believe bone samples offer the first evidence a black sailor was among the crew.

item.title: Aimee Fuller: Olympian tests 'flying surfboard' on Thames
item.description: Olympic snowboarder Aimee Fuller takes an electric surfboard for a spin on the River Thames.

item.title: Pride month: Five stories from around the world
item.description: From Canada to Uganda, people are celebrating Pride, both as a protest for LGBT rights and as a party.

item.title: âIt all could have all ended for me that day'
item.description: Sean O'Hare suffered a double stroke, but 10 months on he regularly hikes in the Mourne Mountains.

item.title: How a patient treated 280 miles from home died on the M11 hard shoulder
item.description: Peggy Copeman, 81, was neglected by a private ambulance service, a coroner concludes.

item.title: ICYMI: Spider-Man meets the Pope
item.description: A nuisance bear, overheated otters and a special guest for the Pope, some of the stories you may have missed this week.

item.title: Long Covid: 'I've blood clots, a braced leg and damaged heart... but I'm home'
item.description: For three months, Bill Wilson lived a nightmare, trapped behind a plastic facemask fighting Covid.

item.title: 'I spent Â£70,000 on pilot training but can't get a job'
item.description: Newly qualified pilots are indebted and jobless as airlines reel from the pandemic, says the industry.

item.title: Martha Lane Fox: Are we ready to live more of our lives online?
item.description: Lockdown has catapulted us into a screen-based "hybrid" reality, says tech pioneer Martha Lane Fox.

item.title: Outcry over South Africa's multiple husbands proposal
item.description: Critics says it would be "un-African" for a woman to have more than one husband at the same time.

item.title: Jack Savoretti takes us on a guided tour of his new musical genre, Europiana
item.description: The star says he's created a new style of music on his seventh album. Find out what that means...

item.title: A billion new trees might not turn Ukraine green
item.description: The country's ambitious target to improve the environment could actually harm biodiversity.

item.title: Matt Hancock: Did ex-health secretary break the law?
item.description: Matt Hancock resigns for breaching social distancing guidelines after photos emerged of him and a colleague embracing.

item.title: Miami building collapse: Fearful relatives hunt news of missing
item.description: Details emerge of the scores unaccounted for in the Florida building collapse.

item.title: Khurshedben Naoroji: The singer who preached nonviolence to bandits
item.description: Khurshedben Naoroji gave up her singing career to preach nonviolence to bandits in India.

item.title: 'Hurt but proud' - what next for Wales after Euro 2020 exit?
item.description: After they are knocked out of Euro 2020, Wales are hurting but "proud" and looking to the future with their young squad.

item.title: Italy 2-1 Austria: 'Italy less than perfect, but Mancini's side dig deep'
item.description: Italy were less than perfect, but Roberto Mancini's side dug deep to overcome Austria in their toughest Euro 2020 test yet, writes Phil McNulty.

item.title: Ireland's Murray replaces injured Jones as Lions captain
item.description: Alun Wyn Jones will miss the British and Irish Lions tour of South Africa because of a shoulder injury and Ireland scrum-half Conor Murray will captain the side instead.

item.title: Asher-Smith claims Olympic 100m spot - but denied British record
item.description: Dina Asher-Smith books her 100m spot at the Tokyo Olympics but is denied a British record as her time is revised down.

item.title: Styrian GP all you need to know: Stats mount up in Verstappen's favour
item.description: The more time goes by, the tougher this year's world championship looks for Lewis Hamilton and Mercedes.

item.title: Malan shines as England hammer Sri Lanka to complete clean sweep
item.description: Dawid Malan makes 76 as England thrash Sri Lanka by 89 runs to wrap up a 3-0 clean sweep in the Twenty20 series.

item.title: Harlequins beat Exeter in pulsating final to win first Premiership title for nine years
item.description: Louis Lynagh's two late tries secure Harlequins their first Premiership title for nine years as they beat Exeter 40-38 in a thrilling final.

item.title: Vaccine passports: How can I prove I've had both my Covid jabs?
item.description: People who've had both Covid jabs may soon be able to avoid quarantine after travel.

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: The government is considering allowing double vaccinated adults to avoid quarantine after travel.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and receptions?
item.description: Restrictions on weddings have been eased across the UK - so how can you now celebrate?

item.title: What are the rules for pubs, restaurants, festivals and gigs?
item.description: The lifting of restrictions is being delayed, which could affect planned events

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Euro 2020 and Covid: How can I watch with my friends?
item.description: Covid rules are making things a bit different for Euro 2020 spectators.

item.title: Travel guide to Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as almost 44 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or coverings?
item.description: Wearing a face covering is currently a legal requirement in many places, but could the rules change as lockdown eases further?

item.title: Covid: How is furlough changing and when will it end?
item.description: Furlough has been extended until the end of September

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Over-18s can get a first jab in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, and second jabs are being brought forward.

item.title: Covid in Scotland: Can we stop worrying about high case numbers?
item.description: As vaccination reduces serious illness from Covid-19, the Scottish government is changing its strategy.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Medical teams around the world are learning which medicines work best against Covid.

item.title: Covid: How is Europe lifting lockdown restrictions?
item.description: Europe is gradually easing lockdown measures ahead of the tourist season.

item.title: Euro 2020: Why are England players self-isolating?
item.description: Two England players are self-isolating after a Scotland player tested positive for Covid.

item.title: Covid: Ivermectin to be studied as possible treatment in UK
item.description: Scientists begin to give the drug to people at home with symptoms to see if it can keep them out of hospital.

item.title: Time: How realistic is the BBC prison drama?
item.description: From blackmail to bullying, those with experience of the inside unpick the hard-hitting BBC drama.

item.title: How vinyl records are trying to go green
item.description: With sales up, some labels and artists are trying to make vinyl more environmentally friendly.

item.title: Mosh pits and no masks at Download Festival pilot
item.description: This weekend's Download Festival is part of a live event trial to see if large-scale gatherings are possible.

item.title: Covid: How have allotments helped people during the pandemic?
item.description: Plot-holders tell how growing their own has helped them deal with grief and sustain mental health.

item.title: In pictures: Scotland fans celebrate England result
item.description: Thousands were in London for the Euro 2020 match against England, while others watched from the Glasgow fan zone.

item.title: A fake wedding, and a $250,000 scam
item.description: How a British man's dreams of a future with his Ukrainian fiancee ended in financial disaster.

item.title: Gary Allen: The killer who nearly got away with murder
item.description: Gary Allen's conviction for the murders of two women brings a 20-year quest for justice to an end.

item.title: Wimbledon: Roger Federer's epic victory over Pete Sampras, 20 years on
item.description: At Wimbledon in 2001, a teenage hopeful took on the serial champion. It was a match for the ages - the only time two greats met.

item.title: The Lazarus heist: How North Korea almost pulled off a billion-dollar hack
item.description: In 2016 North Korean hackers planned a $1bn raid on Bangladesh's national bank and came within an inch of success. But how did they do it?

item.title: Daniel Morgan: Last chance for family in Britain's most-investigated, unsolved murder
item.description: The death of Daniel Morgan is Britain's most investigated unsolved murder. His family believe police corruption, and reluctance to confront it, could explain the murder and the failed investigations
